title: What is at the Boundary between Order and Chaos? Truth, Goodness, Beauty? Creativity? Love? Courage?
description:
Karen and Brett discuss Truth, Goodness and Beauty through the lens of Jordan Peterson's Maps of Meaning and Per Bok's book about self-organizing criticality.

Notes follow this list of resources:
Nima Arkani Hamed's lecture on the Morality of Fundamental Physics
https://youtu.be/5aAMJNVmdoY

D C Schindler's lecture on Beauty and Love
https://youtu.be/ei6eRK28oac

Genetic epistemology
Assimilation v. Accommodation
Assimilation: we use our cognitive structure to act in the world, use it to change the world.
Accommodation: we allow our cognitive structure to change.

Pathologies related to that - too much assimilation and we suppress the anomaly and don't learn. Too much accommodation and we give the anomaly too much power in our lives. Rather, cultivate hopeful uncertainty.

You need courage to act on your convictions and to allow yourself to dissolve. Humility is courage. Truth takes courage. Courage is required at the sticking point of every virtue.

Nihilism is the refusal to take responsibility, but the fool is the precursor to the savior. He has the courage to be a fool, to dwell in uncertainty (humility).

Nihilism - having no value structure, no action.
Radical nihilism is valuing NOTHINGNESS.

Goodness:  Robert Wright, author of Non-Zero speaks of
cultural evolution moving towards increasing complexity, that which emerges at the border of order and chaos. Communication is intimately tied up in this processs. The parts of the system align themselves as a whole, align their interests. Communication requires the ability to tell the truth, and that makes us more adaptable towards the good.

When organisms align their interests, they self-organize to the critical state.
Self-organized criticality is essential to the flow state. Having sufficient skill is a necessary precursor to getting into the flow state and contribute to the cultural complexity. JBP would say another way to align is via error. When we reach the limits of our knowledge, when we err, we meet with the Transcendent.
